text: Whoever is "seeding" the markets is doing so with no delay

text: I suspect in the early days there was good money to be made court-siding in tennis, but I doubt it would be worth anything now. The market (and Betfair) is too sophisticated for that

elements.text: I suspect in the early days there was good money to be made court-siding in tennis, but I doubt it would be worth anything now. The market (and Betfair) is too sophisticated for that

text: If you look how the market works now, I suspect it has been like this for a couple of years. And with tennis, a lot (most) of the tournaments have been run without any spectators. So you can guarantee no court-siding for most tennis tournaments now. And guess what? No change. Puts paid to the idea that markets are influenced by court-siders

elements.text: If you look how the market works now, I suspect it has been like this for a couple of years. And with tennis, a lot (most) of the tournaments have been run without any spectators. So you can guarantee no court-siding for most tennis tournaments now. And guess what? No change. Puts paid to the idea that markets are influenced by court-siders

text: Oh I guess real quick, so would you say you are still very concerned with making sure you cancel bids and orders relatively quickly? And do you think you can sometimes catch people who fail to cancel well? Or is the game really much more about just an accurate pricing after any given point, and that kind of speed crap is more taken care of by the delay? If that's not too much to ask.

And do you think you can sometimes catch people who fail to cancel well?
